summary.p: The STANDARD mode provides the latest recommended default values that should be safe to run in most scenarios
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The IN_REGION mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for applications which call AWS services from within the same AWS region
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The CROSS_REGION mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for applications which call AWS services in a different region
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The MOBILE mode builds on the standard mode and includes optimization tailored for mobile applications
Note that the default values vended from this mode might change as best practices may evolve. As a result, it is encouraged to perform tests when upgrading the SDK
The AUTO mode is an experimental mode that builds on the standard mode. The SDK will attempt to discover the execution environment to determine the appropriate settings automatically.

Note that the auto detection is heuristics-based and does not guarantee 100% accuracy. STANDARD mode will be used if the execution environment cannot be determined. The auto detection might query EC2 Instance Metadata service, which might introduce latency. Therefore we recommend choosing an explicit defaults_mode instead if startup latency is critical to your application
The LEGACY mode provides default settings that vary per SDK and were used prior to establishment of defaults_mode

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Internal.AmazonManagedBlockchainQueryEndpointResolver
member.summary: Amazon ManagedBlockchainQuery endpoint resolver. Custom PipelineHandler responsible for resolving endpoint and setting authentication parameters for ManagedBlockchainQuery service requests. Collects values for ManagedBlockchainQueryEndpointParameters and then tries to resolve endpoint by calling ResolveEndpoint method on GlobalEndpoints.Provider if present, otherwise uses ManagedBlockchainQueryEndpointProvider. Responsible for setting authentication and http headers provided by resolved endpoint.

Container for the parameters to the BatchGetTokenBalance operation. Gets the token balance for a batch of tokens by using the BatchGetTokenBalance action for every token in the request.
Only the native tokens BTC,ETH, and the ERC-20, ERC-721, and ERC 1155 token standards are supported.

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListAssetContractsRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the ListAssetContracts operation. Lists all the contracts for a given contract type deployed by an address (either a contract address or a wallet address).
The Bitcoin blockchain networks do not support this operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListAssetContractsRequest.ContractFilter
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ContractFilter.
Contains the filter parameter for the request.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListAssetContractsRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
The maximum number of contracts to list.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListAssetContractsRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListAssetContractsResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListAssetContracts operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListAssetContractsResponse.Contracts
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Contracts.
An array of contract objects that contain the properties for each contract.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListAssetContractsResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTokenBalancesRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the ListTokenBalances operation. This action returns the following for a given blockchain network:
Lists all token balances owned by an address (either a contract address or a wallet address).
Lists all token balances for all tokens created by a contract.
Lists all token balances for a given token.
You must always specify the network property of the tokenFilter when using this operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTokenBalancesRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
The maximum number of token balances to return.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTokenBalancesRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTokenBalancesRequest.OwnerFilter
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OwnerFilter.
The contract or wallet address on the blockchain network by which to filter the request. You must specify the address property of the ownerFilter when listing balances of tokens owned by the address.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTokenBalancesRequest.TokenFilter
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TokenFilter.
The contract address or a token identifier on the blockchain network by which to filter the request. You must specify the contractAddress property of this container when listing tokens minted by a contract.
You must always specify the network property of this container when using this operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTokenBalancesResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListTokenBalances operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTokenBalancesResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTokenBalancesResponse.TokenBalances
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TokenBalances.
An array of TokenBalance objects. Each object contains details about the token balance.

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionEventsRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListTransactionEvents operation. An array of TransactionEvent objects. Each object contains details about the transaction event.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionEventsRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
The maximum number of transaction events to list.
Even if additional results can be retrieved, the request can return less results than maxResults or an empty array of results.
To retrieve the next set of results, make another request with the returned nextToken value. The value of nextToken is null when there are no more results to return

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionEventsRequest.Network
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Network.
The blockchain network where the transaction events occurred.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionEventsRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionEventsRequest.TransactionHash
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TransactionHash.
The hash of the transaction. It is generated whenever a transaction is verified and added to the blockchain.

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionEventsResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListTransactionEvents operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionEventsResponse.Events
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Events.
An array of TransactionEvent objects. Each object contains details about the transaction events.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionEventsResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionsRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListTransactions operation. Lists all of the transactions on a given wallet address or to a specific contract.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionsRequest.Address
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Address.
The address (either a contract or wallet), whose transactions are being requested.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionsRequest.FromBlockchainInstant
member.summary: Gets and sets the property FromBlockchainInstant.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.ListTransactionsRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
The maximum number of transactions to list.
Even if additional results can be retrieved, the request can return less results than maxResults or an empty array of results.
To retrieve the next set of results, make another request with the returned nextToken value. The value of nextToken is null when there are no more results to return

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.TokenIdentifier.TokenId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TokenId.
The unique identifier of the token.
You must specify this container with btc for the native BTC token, and eth for the native ETH token. For all other token types you must specify the tokenId in the 64 character hexadecimal tokenid format.

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.Transaction
member.summary:
There are two possible types of transactions used for this data type:
A Bitcoin transaction is a movement of BTC from one address to another.
An Ethereum transaction refers to an action initiated by an externally owned account, which is an account managed by a human, not a contract. For example, if Bob sends Alice 1 ETH, Bob's account must be debited and Alice's must be credited. This state-changing action occurs within a transaction.

member.name: P:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.Model.Transaction.BlockHash
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BlockHash.
The block hash is a unique identifier for a block. It is a fixed-size string that is calculated by using the information in the block. The block hash is used to verify the integrity of the data in the block.

member.name: T:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.AmazonManagedBlockchainQueryClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing ManagedBlockchainQuery
Amazon Managed Blockchain (AMB) Query provides you with convenient access to multi-blockchain network data, which makes it easier for you to extract contextual data related to blockchain activity. You can use AMB Query to read data from public blockchain networks, such as Bitcoin Mainnet and Ethereum Mainnet. You can also get information such as the current and historical balances of addresses, or you can get a list of blockchain transactions for a given time period. Additionally, you can get details of a given transaction, such as transaction events, which you can further analyze or use in business logic for your applications.

member.name: M:Amazon.ManagedBlockchainQuery.AmazonManagedBlockchainQueryClient.#ctor
member.summary:
Constructs AmazonManagedBlockchainQueryClient with the credentials loaded from the application's default configuration, and if unsuccessful from the Instance Profile service on an EC2 instance.
Example App.config with credentials set.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="AWSProfileName" value="AWS Default"/> </appSettings> </configuration>

Lists all token balances owned by an address (either a contract address or a wallet address).
